div.p: HUMBLE PROPOSALS FOR THE Relief, Encouragement, Security and Happine≈øs of the Loyal, Couragious Seamen of England, in their Lives and Payment, in the Service of our Mo≈øt Gracious King William, and the Defence of the≈øe Nations.
Humbly Pre≈øented to the Two Mo≈øt Honourable Hou≈øes, the Lords and Commons of England, in Parliament A≈ø≈øembled.
By a Faithful Subject of his Maje≈øty, and Servant to the Parliament and Nation, and the Seamen of England; in order for Safety and Security of all afore≈øaid, W. Hodges.
To which is added, A DIALOGUE concerning the Art of Ticket-buying.

div.head: To the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons in Parliament A≈ø≈øembled, Humbly ≈øheweth,
div.p: THAT the Providence of our mo≈øt gracious God, having ≈øtirred me up to ≈øee, and con≈øider, and lament the mo≈øt dreadful Ruin and De≈øtruction of the Loyal Seamen of England, in their Lives and Pay, that ever the≈øe Nations did behold, and to Repre≈øent the ≈øame in all Humility to your Honours; and con≈øidering al≈øo, that ≈øome of their Mi≈øeries were, in my Judgment, again≈øt Grace, and Rea≈øon and Common Sen≈øe; and al≈øo ≈øometimes again≈øt tho≈øe other Four Things that u≈øed to be e≈øteemed of as Jewels in England; that is, Religion, Liberty, Property, and their Lives: To ≈øay nothing of the Fifth, without Law, made me to dread the Con≈øequent; and I did ob≈øerve that it was hidden from his Maje≈øty and your Honours ≈øo long, until there was the Lo≈øs, as I repre≈øented to you, of the Lives of above Forty Thou≈øand, and of the Pay of above Sixty Thou≈øand of them; and if there had been occa≈øion to que≈øtion the Truth of it, I would have proved at any time by the King's Books, in twenty Four Days time, without Two Pence Charge to the King or Nation; and con≈øidering that his Maje≈øty has ≈øpoken for their Relief, and your Honours, who had rai≈øed money enough before to have kept them from Ruin, and to have ≈øpared a Million or Two of it by Capt. St. Lo's Rule.

Be≈øides, if they had been but managed as the Engli≈øh Seamen were in former days, and as the Dutch and the French do at this day, to ≈øave near half their money, and mo≈øt of their Seamens Lives. But I ≈øay, Your Honours being now al≈øo Re≈øolved to ≈øtudy their Relief, I pre≈øume, in all Humility, to ca≈øt in my Mite al≈øo. Now, in order to the
≈øame, which I would intreat your Honours to accept of, as Rough and Unframed Timber, to be ≈øquared and fitted to what part your Honours plea≈øe; and one thing is, many crooked pieces are made u≈øe of in the building of Shipping, that when placed aright not only ≈øerve to ≈øtrengthen the Ship, and help to pre≈øerve the Lives of the Seamen, but formally u≈øe to help tohold the Ships together, while they daily beat their Enemies; and tho the≈øe Pieces may not be always ≈øo readily known to all Landmen, I will pre≈øume ≈øome may ≈øerve now, and ≈øome another time.

And I do a≈ø≈øure your Honours, if I had better at hand, I would pre≈øent them to you: But they are my own, and ≈øo ≈øaved me the trouble of begging, borrowing, or which is wor≈øe, ≈øtealing; and I intreat your Honours Patience; for their Mi≈øeries being ≈øo dreadful, and ≈øo many years a growing, and ≈øo many times Ten Thou≈øands, as they could not have been ea≈øily repre≈øented, except one ≈øhould have ≈øaid, their Ca≈øe was almo≈øt all together Mi≈øerable: But ble≈ø≈øed be God that it is not: They have a good King and good Countrey for their Friends, if their Ca≈øes are not blinded from them: And as to their Remedies, it requires a great deal of Care and Inquiry: And when I look back to what I repre≈øented before; and forward, to what ≈øtrange need there is of them now, and when I hear that a great many there is that are in Droves, travelling in other Countries without Shooes or Stockings, ≈øeeking to enter into the Service of the Merchants of England there, or to ≈øerve other Nations, and Run away from che Merchant-Ships al≈øo, and lo≈øe their Pay, ≈øome of them not being willing to come home, for fear of the Pre≈øs; This makes my Heart dread the Effects of it, and do ≈øuppo≈øe the≈øe Two Things would be worth while to be inquired into by the Parliament, to know how the Ca≈øe ≈øtands with them in the≈øe re≈øpects.
Fir≈øt, Let every Man of War's Book, that hath been in the Streights, or Spain, or Portugal, be ≈øearched, to ≈øee what Numbers Run away out of any Ship, or every Ship, at any Port or Place.

And, Secondly, To have an Account of the Men of War and Merchant-Ships lo≈øt this Eighteen Months to the French, with the whole Number of Men taken in each Ship, and in the whole Shipping lo≈øt; and then have al≈øo the Number of Men return'd from France in that time, that did belong to tho≈øe Ships, and what is wanting may be ≈øuppo≈øed to be entred into the French Service, if not dead; and if
of the Ea≈øt-India Ships taken, there be come home ≈øhort, near an Hundred of tho≈øe men that were taken; it is to be fear'd, the re≈øt will ≈øtay until warm weather, and then get ≈øome Money and Cloaths, if our Pre≈øs is ≈øo great this Winter, that they meet the poor Captive Wretches when they Return home in their Lou≈øie Cloaths from France, and beg their way near an Hundred and Fifty Miles; then before they come to London, catch them, and carry them on Board, Rags and Lice, as they Run; put them down in the Hold of the Ve≈ø≈øel, to lie on the Boards or Balla≈øt, or what they plea≈øe, if they be without Bedding; and as Queen E≈øther ≈øaid, if they peri≈øh, they peri≈øh.

This is a Notable Age to tame Prodigals in, if they be ordinary Seamen; but if they be Double-Pay Officers, then it may be they Run up and down, and be as bad or wor≈øe than before; and ≈øo it may be will not be worth, ≈øome of them, a Groat a Dozen, when the War is over; tho they mo≈øt times Live; For the Officers that have Liberty to come on Shore, die very few of them. But this by the way. But I am too large in the Introduction.

I did think to ≈øay ≈øomething more as to the Seamen's Encouragement, in this Preface; as that without the Seamen be paid off yearly on Shore, and have a Fortnight's or Month's Liberty to Recruit their Healths, I am afraid they will never be encouraged to come into the Service, neither ≈øtay there; and if they do, and die, it is as bad as Running; for if they Run away in England, and the Merchants get them, it is an help to Trade, and the King may have them again; and I could never know the Rea≈øon of that pretence of keeping the Seamen in ≈øuch ≈ølavery in their payments, in this Age more than any other, to be paid on Board; as if his Maje≈øty's Service was not as good as in any Age of the World. For my part, I ≈øay, according to the money rai≈øed, there could never have been better Pay for the Seamen in the world. And indeed I would not have the Seamen of England ≈øay Ju≈øtly, That God and the King ≈øent good Meat, but the Devil ≈øent them Cooks that ≈øpoil'd it half in dre≈ø≈øing.
But in ≈øhort, I cannot ≈øee how the Nation, in the general, can an≈øwer the Seamen's being left to Ruin:
For, Fir≈øt, as I ≈øaid, it is again≈øt Grace, again≈øt the gracious Law of Chri≈øt, not to do to them as we would others ≈øhould do to us; which is taught the Children in their Catechi≈øms.

2. It is again≈øt the gracious Providence of God to the≈øe Nations, who did, by a Miracle, ≈øend over our gracious King William, to be a means to ≈øecure our Religion, Liberties and Properties; and if the Nation, who enjoys all the≈øe in Peace at home, ≈øhould let the Seamen be Ruined, and lo≈øe all together, and their Lives into the bargain; I am afraid Chri≈øt will tell us another word in our Ears, That the Scripture ≈øhall not fail; and the ≈øame mea≈øure men mete, ≈øhall be meted to them again.
And ≈øo much to their being managed contrary to Grace.

2. Contrary to Rea≈øon; for Rea≈øon tells us, other Ages encouraged their Seamen, and paid them on Shore; and other Nations do ≈øo now. And Rea≈øon may tell tho≈øe who have under≈øtood the Nature of the paying on Board, That the Seamen's Families and Relations have not enjoyed the Benefit of little more than half their Pay, to their Familie's Comfort.

3. It is contrary to common ≈øen≈øe, to think that if Seamen do u≈øually die, great part, where they are kept 2 or 3 years on board, that they ≈øhould have any Policy to keep them until they die, rather than to pay them off, to Recruit their Health and Lives.

And indeed, who could be ever imagined to come freely into that Service where nothing but Death can part again, and then the Widow denied their Mony oft-times at la≈øt. And be≈øides the Lo≈øs of the Seamen's Lives, there is extraordinary Charge to the Nation, and no benefit to the publick; but it may be the Commanders that had abu≈øed the Seamen all the War, could not get more, and would want a Ship to get Mony in, and ≈øo might want bread, while our brave Commanders would have Men enough But tho≈øe who have driven away the Seamen from their Ships, and could have a ≈øupply by turning over men from other Ships, the≈øe might be at a Lo≈øs for Men next Year. But my Skill in Sea Affairs is too ≈ømall: Did it but attain to the heighth of my Faithulne≈øs to his Maje≈øty, and Love to my Native Country, I would, if the Lord a≈ø≈øi≈øted me with Life and
Health, write ≈øuch an Hi≈øtory of the Knavery, Folly, Cowardize, Treachery, Ruin and De≈øtruction of this War; in the Sea-Affairs, the Land would admire at; and would write every Line, to the be≈øt of my Judgment, what would be found true, not only in another Age, where they will ≈øpeak plainly, how his Maje≈øty, and the Parliament, and Nation, and Merchants are cheated and abu≈øed. But I would write what I believe will be found true in the Day of Judgment, where all Cloaks will be thrown off; and then it will be known, that God did not ≈øend Mankind into the world to be like Fi≈øhes, the great ones to devour the little ones; and I ble≈øs the Lord, who kept me from being one of the Devourers of the Age; for I have had an opportunity with ea≈øe to be a Mon≈øter, when I laid out an hundred Pound a week, or two, in Seamen's Pay, if I had bought at half Profit, or Twelve Shillings in the Pound Profit, as ≈øome Mon≈øters did, I ≈øhould have doubled my Mony ≈øo often, to have been able to have ≈øwallowed up 3 or 4 Seamen's Pay for a Breakfa≈øt, be≈øides what I had for Dinner and Supper; and then I ≈øhould never have ≈øaid a word of the Ruin of the Seamen, but ≈øhould have been forc'd to have kept all Coun≈øel, if the King had been cheated of a quarter of his Money, and the Seamen of above half their pay.

But I pre≈øume it will be well to look back to the mo≈øt happy ≈øtate of our Ships of War, when we did mo≈øt effectually beat our Enemies, and incourage our Seamen, and ≈øee if we do not find the neglect of their method hath been the Lo≈øs of half our Seamen, and many of our Ships.

And, Secondly, Whether their way was not to go out in the Summer, and take all Opportunities to ≈øight and de≈øtroy their Enemies, and come in again with the greate≈øt part of the Fleet, and pay off the Seamen, and ≈øave their Lives and Pay.

Whether if this had been done, the Seamen would not have been incouraged to come freely into the King's Service, as in other Ages, as into a place where there was Mony, and Liberty, and Relea≈øe, and not perpetual Bondage. And if at la≈øt di≈øcharged by rea≈øon of Sickne≈øs, and had Tickets ≈øigned by all the ≈øigning Officers, for the ≈øame to be deprived, otherwi≈øe cheated publickly of their mony, to the ≈øhame of the Pay, and the Ruin of the di≈øcharged; and whether any can now, on the la≈øt Terms,
be ≈øafe to ≈øerve their King and Country: and it may be que≈øtioned, whether it be not a ≈øhameful thing, when poor Seamen have had their Pay received by fal≈øe Powers, they ≈øhould be denied the ≈øight of the Ship's Books, to ≈øee who received it; and therefore whether al≈øo this, and the denying them otherwi≈øe the knowledg of their Ca≈øe, be not an unju≈øt and unrea≈øonable thing to let poor Creatures be Cheated and Ruined, and hide it from them. And what advantage it is to the Government, to let their poor Seamen be ≈øo managed, be≈øides the King's being at extraordinary Charge to pay them ≈øo far from London, and the City deprived of the benefit of taking their mony, as in other Ages, wherein the City of London was not u≈øed to be ≈øo ≈ølighted, neither the Seamen ≈øo Ruined.

But I ≈øhall pre≈øume to ≈øay more in the Body of my Book; for whoever plea≈øeth to read it at their lei≈øure, what my Thoughts are; and if the Honourable Hou≈øes pardon me, I ≈øhall not need much to trouble my ≈øelf with the Offences any others may take at it; for I write for good, and not to plea≈øe, but to hinder Cheating the King, and Ruining the Seamen; and not to flatter tho≈øe that would have it all ≈ømuggled up in ≈øilence; which makes me think of one lately, that becau≈øe he could not find any thing fal≈øe in my book, had this ≈øuppo≈øition, and that was, That he ≈øuppo≈øed if I had Repre≈øented ≈øo much in France, the French King would have hanged me.
Now to that, being only a Suppo≈øition, I will an≈øwer it with other Suppo≈øitions: As,

1. I mu≈øt have been a Fool or a Knave to have writ it, if I did not con≈øult before I writ it, whether I could, with a good Con≈øcience, have ≈øuffered Death for the ≈øame; and if I could, that might have been an ea≈øier Death than the Stone or the Gout. And,

2. I ≈øuppo≈øe, by his Leave, if the French King's Subjects are Ruined and De≈øtroyed, it is by his Knowledge and Appointment; and not Ruined and de≈øtroyed without his knowledge, and the knowledge of his Nobles, as I pre≈øume our Seamen's Ruin are hid from the King and Parliament, and the blame mu≈øt at la≈øt lie ≈øomewhere; and it may be the next Age will wonder at ≈øhe Hi≈øtory of it; therefore I take pains to inform the King and Parliament, that they may let the blame and ≈øhame be
laid on tho≈øe who have been Unju≈øt, and Cruel, and Barbarous in the management of the Ruined Seamen and their Families: And indeed I ≈øuppo≈øe al≈øo,

3. That the French King, tho he plagues almo≈øt all Mankind, yet he incourages his Seamen, let's them come on ≈øhore every Year, and mony in their Pocket; lends them his Men of War to Privateer in, gives them his Tenths; and in ≈øhort, if they have gotten Three Millions of Riches this Year from us, his Seamen's Share is more Hundreds of Thou≈øands of Pounds than would pay our Ruined Seamen all their Q's and R's.

4. I ≈øuppo≈øe if he had ≈øeen his Seamen had been half dead, or frightned away, or Cheated of their Pay, and he not known it before-hand, I prote≈øt I do not only ≈øuppo≈øe, but really conclude they would have been more likely to have hang'd ≈øome that ruined his Seamen, for being Knaves to do it; and tho≈øe that ≈øeemed hone≈øt, for being Tools to con≈øent to it; and that might have e≈øcaped well next time, or at lea≈øt had as good Quarter for telling as they for acting.

And ≈øuppo≈øe one Suppo≈øition more, That if the French King did know that his Admiralty, and Navy-Board, and Commanders of Ships did Ruin and de≈øtroy his Seamen's Lives and Pay, the Seamen would not ≈øo con≈øtantly go home to France again as they do; neither would he have Men enough to man his Fleet; neither would any other means ≈øecure his Seamen's Lives and Pay, without Managers that were as merciful to them as good men are to their Bea≈øts, who do not let them groan and cry, and langui≈øh away for want of that Provender that is due to them for their Labour, for that day's work wherein they fell ≈øick under their Burden, which is too ≈øad, and too tedious to inlarge on.

And if your Honours think it to be too tedious, it may be con≈øidered, That the Mi≈øeries of the Seamen in England, have been of more various Kinds, and peradventure various Numbers than the Mi≈øeries of all the Corporations of England, and cannot be Repre≈øented in a few Words; be≈øides all their other Mi≈øeries of their Families that they are ≈øubject to, equal with the lo≈øt of Mankind; And as their Di≈øea≈øes are many, they require hone≈øt faithful Doctors, in order to their Cure, and not leave them in the hands of hard hearted Wretches, to Ruin
them. But I could write until I tire your Honours and my ≈øelf. But I beg your Honour's Gracious Pardon, and do lay my ≈øelf at your Honour's Feet, and beg of God to give his Maje≈øty Wi≈ødom, as an Angel of God; and that God would fill your Honours with all Wi≈ødom, and that in his and your Pro≈øperity the Nation may be happy and ble≈ø≈øed; and then I hope I ≈øhall in mercy injoy a ≈øhare of the ≈øame; Who ≈øub≈øcribe my ≈øelf a faithful Lover and Servant to his mo≈øt Gracious Maje≈øty King William, and all your Honours, and all good men, while I remain,

div.head: Propo≈øals, &c.
div.p:
THE Subject of Encouraging and Increa≈øing of our Engli≈øh Seamen, is of greater Con≈øequence than abundance of Mankind doth readily apprehend; and we being an I≈øland, cannot be ≈øafe or happy in Peace or War without them; which makes me admire what ≈øen≈øle≈øs Stuff the Brains of tho≈øe are, or what hardened metal their Hearts are, that have ≈øo greatly Ruined and Oppre≈ø≈øed many of them and their Families; and I have admired and lamented with Tears, to under≈øtand their Ruin: And if God him≈øelf commanded the Jews ≈øo ≈øtrictly, That if they ≈øaw their Enemie's Ox or A≈øs fall down under their Burden, they ≈øhould help them up; Then God forbid I ≈øhould have my Heart harder than a Jew, that when I ≈øee not my Enemie's A≈ø≈øes, but my mo≈øt gracious Soveraign King William's, and my dear Country's Seamen, many dead under their burdens, and others in Ditches of mi≈øery, if I ≈øhould not endeavour to help them up, I ≈øhould be wor≈øe than a Jew. And I con≈øidering, and ≈øeeing their mi≈øeries thrown on them, and endeavouring ≈øome Years to help them out, until I did almo≈øt fall in my ≈øelf, I cried out for help to their Ma≈øter and Dame, who immediately ≈øent a large ≈øupply of Mony to their Managers and Drivers, to a≈ø≈øi≈øt them and help them up; and at fir≈øt they had help. But the poor Cattle being kept travelling ≈øo long, until they fell ≈øick by Droves; and when they that drove them ≈øaw they were ≈øick, and could be drove no farther, either let them die with the Load on their backs, but if others let them out to
Pa≈øture, then there was an Order, That if they could not be well, to come into the ≈øame Drove in 28 Days, they mu≈øt then run the hazard to lo≈øe all the Hay and Corn due to them and their Young; altho it may be many of them died within a few Days after they were in Pa≈øture; or it may be the Drove, they belonged to, was gone 300 miles before they were well; and it may be they went into the next Drove of their Ma≈øters they met with, if they lived, and were well; or it may be they continued ≈øick, and were ≈øent into ≈øome Stable for Cure, and there did continue long after their Drivers had ruined the Re≈øt of their Fother: And I con≈øidering what a Scarcity of others to bear the Burdens, and ≈øo Extraordinary Charge to buy more, that I thought it better to keep them there was, and prevent that hazard and Charge, e≈øpecially con≈øidering be≈øides, That it was a ≈øign of mens being wicked, who≈øe tender mercies were cruel; And al≈øo, that the young ones they bought, did many times die before they were a Year u≈øed to the Pack-Saddle.
And to conclude, I dreamed, That without there were hone≈øt, faithful Managers, Drivers and Ho≈øtlers, the poor Cattle would be ruined at la≈øt.

And now I come to ≈øpeak of peace, I de≈øire the Lord in mercy to ≈øend a good one, if we wait a Year longer or two before it comes; and our Seamen will need help in Merchant-Ships. And indeed ≈øome of our Merchant-Ships, the Ma≈øters are ≈øhame
‚Ä¢ e≈øsly ≈øcandalou≈øly Villains, in going the way to cheat and oppre≈øs
the Seamen: And the≈øe may be reputed among the cur≈øed Ticket-buyers, and barbarous Villains that ruin the Seamen in Men of War; For many of the Ma≈øters in Merchant Ships ≈øtop what they plea≈øe out of their pay, or do make them go to Law for their Wages, and keep them out oftentimes al≈øo 2 or 3 months, tho the poor Seamen are pre≈øt away; And one in particular lately did ≈øell his Seaman's Venture, and kept his pay, and the Seaman pre≈øt away; and the Ma≈øter did promi≈øe me his mony from day to day, until he cunningly, in the Night, carried his Ship to Grave≈øend, and got her cleer'd. But I heard of it in the morning, and ≈øent away an Officer to the Ship, and got him arre≈øted to make him hone≈øt; and got the mony from the ≈øcandalous Villain. But if Merchant Seamen were incouraged as follows:

49. Fir≈øt, That there might be a Law made, That all Seamen might have as good and large allowance of all Provi≈øions and Beer, as in his Maje≈øtie's Ships; and in ca≈øe of falling ≈øhort, on any occa≈øion, to be paid ≈øhort allowance mony al≈øo.

50. That none might pay any dammage, except for their own Neglect or Fault. And this would be the way for Ma≈øters and Owners to take care to ≈øend better Ships to Sea, and not oppre≈øs the Seamen for their Rotten Leaky Ships Fault.

51. No Seamen to have undue Correction, nor indeed no extraordinary Correction, without the Approbation of the Ma≈øter, and 2 of the Officers, that ≈øo men might not be barbarou≈øly killed in the Ships, as ≈øome have been, and others dreadfully abu≈øed.

52. That the Ma≈øters who ≈øtop 2 or 3 months pay a piece from the Seamen, when they pay them, unju≈øtly, may be puni≈øhed as Villains, that do go the way to di≈øcourage, and bring a Cur≈øe on our Engli≈øh Navigation, if it lay in their power. Whereas tho≈øe hone≈øt Ma≈øters, that Victual well, and pay well, are ≈øuch as go the way to incourage our Engli≈øh Navigation, and to procure a ble≈ø≈øing on the ≈øame; and the≈øe Ma≈øters I love; but I hate all ≈øorts of Villany and Knavery wherever I meet with it in any: And do therefore expect to hear of ≈øome Knaves find Fault with this, as ≈øome Thieves and Cheats did when they heard I did di≈øcover to the Parliament how the King and Nation was cheated. But I wonder they ≈øhould be ≈øuch Fools to complain,
≈øeeing I named no body; And if they had laughed at it, no body had need to have known they had been guilty them≈øelves: And ≈øo I wi≈øh them to be wi≈øer next time; And tho there are Abundance of Cheats and Villains to Cheat the King and Country, I know their methods, and am a≈øhamed that ≈øo brave and excellent a King, and ≈øo famous and fine a Country, and ≈øuch Stout, Loyal, brave Seamen, the be≈øt in the Univer≈øal World, ≈øhould be all cheated and abu≈øed, and that many times by tho≈øe who drink it away, or whore it away, or game it away. Again, and if one Devil helps them to get it, there is ≈øo many Devils to help to ≈øpend it, that ≈øome of them will not be worth one Groat a Dozen, in a Years time after the War is over, and nothing ≈øtirring but Hone≈øty and Indu≈øtry.

But 53. There ought to be ≈øome care taken that Ma≈øters of Ships might not abu≈øe, and cheat, and beat, and ≈øtarve their Seamen beyond Sea; for that hath cau≈øed multitudes of Engli≈øhmen to run away in the Straits, and other Voyages, to the great di≈øcouragement of our brave Engli≈øh Seamen, who will do anything, if incouraged; but will be mad, and run away to ≈øerve any Nation, yea even the Turks them≈øelves, if they are Abu≈øed.

54. It is pity there is not more liberal incouragement for Seamen to carry Ventures, and to be extraordinary well provided with provi≈øions in their Voyages to the Ea≈øt Indies, ≈øince many Ships have in that Voyage, of tho≈øe they carried out, buried 4 men to One of tho≈øe which they did bring home: And that is bad, to lo≈øe all to a fifth part. And many men have in that Voyage been ≈øuppo≈øed to die for want. And the Company ≈øuffereth by it in the danger of their Goods, if Ships mi≈øcarry. Whereas tho≈øe Brave Worthy Commanders, who Victual extraordinary well, and take great care of their men, do come home well, and their men love them, and I love them al≈øo for their Hone≈øty and love to the Seamen. But it is a ≈øhame that any Ship's Commanders ≈øhould be ≈øo unnatural as to want water almo≈øt ≈øo ≈øoon as they come out of the Harbour: And if there were a Law made, That all Seamen in Merchant Ships ≈øhould be paid the full for their ≈øhort Allowance and Water-mony, as the King doth; And that would be the Way to incourage the Seamen to keep their Ships, and not run away to ≈øerve other Nations for want
of better u≈øage. And the Commanders of all Ships, for time to come, ought at lea≈øt to be made to provide Water for their Ship's Company, and not neglect it, or fraught their Ships ≈øo full that they have no room for Water, that ≈øo the poor Seamen may not be whipt at the Geers for drinking the Water that is allow'd for the Hogs. This ≈øeems to be wor≈øe than the poor prodigal Son was ≈øerved: And indeed I have ob≈øerved, That the Interlopers Ships to India, that their men had liberty to carry good Ventures, have gone well, and their men come home as fat as Pigs almo≈øt; as if they had not only had enough of Water, but had eaten half the Hogs al≈øo. And indeed it is al≈øo,

55. Great pity that ≈øo many poor mi≈øerable people were forced to come and wait, and wait and come 20 times for their mony after it is due, for 4 months pay, at the Ea≈øt India-Hou≈øe. The lo≈øs of time to many, and their labour, and waiting ≈øometimes 3 or 4 hours in a day, is worth to ≈øome, I fear, if they reckon their Time, above half the mony. But this Age ≈øeems to play with mi≈øery. I meet with ≈øo many Objects of this Age's being hardned again≈øt the Groans of the poor, in ≈øome places, and Cries of the Poor, that truly I mu≈øt needs fear that the mo≈øt merciful God will ari≈øe to plead the Cau≈øe of the Poor, the Oppre≈ø≈øed, the Fatherle≈øs and the Widow, ≈øeeing many men ≈øeem to lo≈øe moral pity. And indeed I am afraid it is gone to look after moral hone≈øty, many mens very Con≈øciences ≈øeeming to be even as it is ≈øaid of ≈øome Fire-Locks, Ca≈øe-hardened: And as it is ≈øaid, That a good man is merciful to his bea≈øt; ≈øo I will ≈øay, that even the tender mercies of many wicked men in this Age, are cruel. But certainly God did not ≈øend men into this World to be like Devils, to plague and afflict mankind. And therefore it were well and convenient;

56. That no Seamen in any Merchant Ship whatever, to be forced to wait above four Weeks after the Ship is in Harbour, for their Money, it being a very great oppre≈ø≈øion on the Seamen, after a long and tedious Voyage, to have no Mony to buy any thing for them≈øelves or Families in three Months time, and thereby Live on Credit, take up their Cloaths and Provi≈øions, at what Prices any will ≈øet on them, to the great Lo≈øs of many Families.

57. But if there were a Law made for the Hearing of the Seamen's being abus'd or cheated of their Pay; and either the Ma≈øters of the Trinity-Hou≈øe, or ≈øome other men, to be as a Court of Con≈øcience to hear the Seamen's Cau≈øe, without Charge, it would ≈øave the poor Seamen's being forc'd to go to Law for their Wages after any Voyage, or for mony to be paid in the time of any Voyage, it might ≈øave a multitude of Charges at Law, or lo≈øs to poor mi≈øerable Seamen, or their Families being often forc'd to give one half to get the other Recovered, after it is Earn'd.

58. Another method for the true management of our Engli≈øh Navigation, is to labour to have both the Commanders and Officers and Seamen, to be brought to a moral Reformation, and al≈øo to a Religious Wor≈øhip, and fear of the God of Heaven and Earth, and Sea, at who≈øe Command are both Winds and Seas, and indeed if God be not ≈øought unto, but in≈øtead thereof, dayly Bla≈øphemed all other ways and means will be too ≈øhort to Expect a real Ble≈ø≈øing, and comfortable Incouragement, as we might wi≈øh; but that the Seamen will be ≈øo much oppre≈øed, and the Ships Ruined and Spoiled, more and more, until there be ≈øome outward Reformation at lea≈øt, if not a true and ≈øound Reformation of Life and Manners. And if the general in≈øtructions printed and given to the Captains and Lieutenants of Ships by the Admiralty, were minded aright, it would mend many things, and therefore de≈øerves to be inquired into, in drawing up the method of the Well-Government of our Ships and men; And the fir≈øt Paragraph of it is, That God be duly wor≈øhipped, and that twice a day, and all Profanene≈øs, Drunkenne≈øs, Swearing and Cur≈øing be di≈øcountenanced and puni≈øhed; and the Commanders that allow it, turned out. And we ≈øhould meet the Lord by Repentance both by Sea and Land; and cry to the Lord, that he would meet us with his mercy, that we may, by Righteou≈øne≈øs, be an exalted Nation, and not for our ≈øins be a ruined people: And therefore,

59. It were well if every Ship in England that carrieth but ten men were bound to carry that excellent Book of the Church of England's Doctrine, the Book of Homilies, to read 2 Homilies every Sunday. And it hath the 39 Articles bound up with it, that all Seafaring men might ≈øee the excellent Doctrine of the
Old Church of England to be for ≈øound Piety and Holine≈øs: And that it may be ≈øaid of the Prophanene≈øs of this Age, That it is ≈øuch a thing as the Fundamental Doctrine of the Church of England abhors: And as it was ≈øaid of Old, of ≈øome that knew not Jo≈øeph, ≈øo it may be ≈øaid of the great Wickedne≈øs of this Age, That it is from ≈øuch as know not God, neither do they truly know, and believe, and practice that true fundamental Doctrine of the Church of England; And it were well if the Reverend Bi≈øhops would con≈øult the great need there is of ≈øuch Laws as may in ≈øome mea≈øure at lea≈øt bring men to as near a Conformity to the ≈øub≈øtantial, Fundamental Holine≈øs, Sobriety, Charity, Ju≈øtice, and all Chri≈øtian, Fundamental Duties of Grace and Holine≈øs that are contained in ≈øo holy a Doctrine.

60. And that every Ship that doth carry 120 men, or more, do carry an able, ≈øober Mini≈øter, to in≈øtruct the Seamen in their Duty towards God, and to reprove the Vices of any one in the Ship; And by their Doctrine and Conver≈øation, to ≈øhew to them that the fundamental Doctrine of the Church of England, is for the Real Service of God and Holine≈øs, and again≈øt all ≈øin; And that they that profe≈øs the Doctrine, and live in Wickedne≈øs, are fal≈øe pretenders to ≈øo holy Doctrine.

61. And therefore that Excellent Act again≈øt Cur≈øing and Swearing, if well executed, will be a good beginning, and a good help towards a moral Reformation. So if the great Debauchery of this Age could be ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed, it would be a good help towards men's coming to con≈øider of a future ≈øtate, and to think, that whatever they are them≈øelves at pre≈øent, yet mankind was created to live to the Glory of God, and to honour him; and not to live like bea≈øts, and wor≈øe than bea≈øts. And the more excellent the fundamental Doctrine of Chri≈øtianity is in any Church or Nation, the greater the condemnation of tho≈øe mu≈øt be that do ≈øin again≈øt the Light of the ≈øame, and will not regard to walk according unto it.

And now having ≈øaid this, I will return again to another incouragement I think there is great need of, altho the Seamen in all Merchant Ships, that go well and come well, in the Merchant's ≈øervice, pay ≈øomething towards the ≈øame; And that is,

62. That all Fleets of Merchant Ships ≈øhould, as much as po≈ø≈øible, keep company, and ≈øtand by one the other, except much over-powered;

63. And tho≈øe that fight ≈øtoutly, as brave Engli≈øhmen, to be incouraged and preferred.
64. And that tho≈øe Seamen that lo≈øe their Lives or Limbs in Merchant ≈øhips, ≈øhould be incouraged, and have Bounty-mony, as in his Maje≈øties ≈øervice they that are Wounded or Kill'd there have.

But now I would not be mi≈øtaken, to think that his Maje≈øty ≈øhould pay it; altho if a Merchant Ship be lo≈øt, it may fall out that his Maje≈øty may lo≈øe 4000 l Cu≈øtom: And were it ≈øo they did fight and ≈øave the Ship and Goods, if there were 20 kill'd, and 10 wounded, if his Maje≈øty paid each of them, or their Families, 20 l it were 200 l and his Maje≈øty would ≈øave 3600 l by the ≈øaving the Ship at la≈øt, and the Merchants, it may be, 30000 l by the bargain al≈øo: And therefore it would be of great u≈øe to the King and to the Merchants, and to the Nation in general, to ≈øave our Ships as much as po≈ø≈øible, and ruin our Enemies as much as po≈ø≈øible, and encourage our Seamen and Ma≈øters to fight, to ≈øave the Ships as much as po≈ø≈øible. But I have often wondred that any Merchants ≈øhould be ≈øo barbarous, or Ma≈øters ≈øo uncharitable, as not to give the Seamens Families one penny of Eucouragement, who laid down their Lives, and ≈øaved their Ships. And ≈øometimes I have heard of ≈øome that have been forc'd to go to Law for their Wages after the Ship was ≈øaved‚ñ™ And as I remember, a Cu≈øtomer of mine was forced to pay the Chirurgeon 3 or 4 l to cure him of his Wounds. Now I did look on this as barbarous: And I do ≈øay, in this re≈øpect, the ≈øervice of his Maje≈øty is much better than the Merchant-men; And would be in many others al≈øo, if it were not for the Fault of Officers, and Officers of divers ≈øorts. But this by the way; for I think we ≈øhould be the mo≈øt happy people under the Face of Heaven, if it were not for the Sins, and Follies, and Bribery, and Knavery and Villany of the Age we live in; Whereby men are Ruined, and plagued and Afflicted more than ever, in ≈øeveral Kinds, both in Men of War and Merchant Ships, and the King and Country lo≈øe by the ≈øame at la≈øt, many Seamen ≈øerving, as is to be feared,
other Nations, by being ≈øo much di≈øcouraged in their own: But I leave that, and would to God that all would indeed leave it in good earne≈øt, and ≈øet them≈øelves to ≈øtudy to ≈øerve God and his Maje≈øty, and the common good of all the≈øe Nations; and in order to it, I think this is one, to incourage all Seamen, as much as po≈ø≈øible, to pre≈øerve our Shipping; and one way was, that, as I ≈øaid, Whoever lo≈øt their Limbs or Lives in defending a Merchant Ship, ≈øhould have Pen≈øions, or Bounty-mony: And I ≈øuppo≈øe, that if there were a Law made, That every one ≈øhould be ≈øo rewarded, every Seaman would be more willing to venture their Lives to ≈øave their Ships: and the very Seamen in Merchant Ships, that went well and came well, would pay 12 d out of every pound towards a Che≈øt to be kept for that purpo≈øe at Greenwich Ho≈øpital, as there is a Che≈øt for the Cripples at Chatham: And there might be a Commi≈ø≈øioner, or 2 or 3, appointed to manage it in time of War and Peace: And in time of War, they that are in Merchant Ships could afford to pay that cheerfully, becau≈øe their Wages is near double; and in time of Peace it might be but 6d in the pound towards the Pen≈øions; and a Clerk or 2 appointed at the ≈øaid Ho≈øpital, to keep all accounts of every mans months pay in England, and to receive the mony, and to pay it out again to the Widow or Aged Parents of all that are kill'd in the defence of Merchant Ships, 20 l and to all that lo≈øe a Limb, or the total u≈øe of a Limb, in the defence of a Merchant Ship, 6 l the year during their Lives; for their Relief; and this to be paid them con≈øtantly: And not to have any Ticket-buyers ≈øuffered to extort half of it from them: And if the ≈øaid ≈øhilling in the pound paid by others, did amount to more, as it might, if gathered faithfully all over the Nation, then the re≈øt to go to the Widows of poor Seamen, or to aged Seamen that were pa≈øt their labour. And it is as great pity, but all indu≈øtrious Seamen ≈øhould be incouraged in England, ≈øeeing I do not remember that ever in all my Life I heard of one Ship, either Merchant Man, or Man of War lo≈øt, becau≈øe the Seamen would not fight; but ≈øo many becau≈øe the Commanders would not fight, that I have been ofter grieved and a≈øhamed to hear of it. And if there were a Law made to incourage the Seamen, I wi≈øh there were al≈øo another, That if the Commander ‚Ä¢ would not fight, they ≈øhould lo≈øe, as afore≈øaid, 2 of their ≈øingers, and be ≈øold for
≈øaves all their days; and if they did ever return, to be hanged, that ≈øo there may not be ≈øo many to di≈øgrace this brave I≈øland with Cowardi≈øe, which hath been, and in ≈øome mea≈øure is, at this day the Terror of their Enemies, the French Fleet; which were pretended to be ≈øuch Mon≈øters before; having run to their Harbours with ≈øhame and di≈øgrace, ≈øince they ≈øee we have an Admiral who with le≈øs than half our Ships did beat them before; and for that we have cau≈øe to ble≈øs God, and live to his Prai≈øe.

And now to ≈øay ≈øomething to ≈øave his Maje≈øty's mony, and the poor Seamens al≈øo, for time to come, I do ≈øuppo≈øe it will be needful for time to come, to make it Felony to commit the≈øe Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øions, viz.
1. To enter 40 mens Names in a Ship's book, that never were in the Ship, nor in the World, and that is bigger; This to be Felony. And this is a Trick of the Devil's Ma≈øterpiece.

2. That no Pur≈øer, or Captain's Clerk, or any other, do give a Li≈øt of 40 or 50 men at a time, that are dead, or run away; that ≈øo, tho the King hath been cheated of their Victuals, he may not be cheated of their Pay; and tho the Pur≈øer might afford their Pay cheap, yet I wondred when I heard One Pur≈øer gave as many Names as there was 3 or 400 l worth received for in a Ship, and the fooli≈øh Knave had but 8 or 10 l for all. Now this Pur≈øer, and they that did find Powers, ought to be tran≈øpor
‚Ä¢ ed on of this Nation, that the Climate may not be infected with their Villany.

3. That no man in the Office be ≈øuffered to change the Chri≈øtian Name of a Seaman in any Ships books, to cheat the man's Friends of his mony, if occa≈øion be: This Exploit looks like the Art of Jugling, if it ≈øhould be practi≈øed; therefore ≈øhould, if di≈øcovered, be puni≈øhed.

4. That none be ≈øuffered to keep men open upon the book a whole Voyage after they are run away, ≈øince this Trick, and tho≈øe before-mentioned, and ≈øome Captains, as I here di≈øcovered to have many hundred pounds worth of Seamens Tickets, and ≈øome other Tricks I know may be plaid, if not prevented, may co≈øt his Maje≈øty it may be 80000 l the Year, and cheat the Seamen Twenty Thou≈øand Pounds to make it up an Hundred Thou≈øand Pounds the Year; and it being hard Times, as I find it is, a penny ≈øav'd will be as good as a peuny got; And if others

And I only repre≈øent the Knavery, and if they will be ≈øo fooli≈øh when they hear it, by their Anger to let others know they are the men, that is their fault; and a guilty con≈øcience needs no accu≈øer. And ≈øo I leave them to their ≈øerious con≈øiderations, to think if they have ≈øouls, how they that are Cheats and Villains here, mu≈øt an≈øwer it hereafter.

And now being come to a conclu≈øion of this, I give up this and my ≈øoul, ≈øpirit, body, and all my Family, and all my affairs, all into the hands of the Eternal Love and Mercy of our mo≈øt gracious God and loving Father in Je≈øus Chri≈øt our only Saviour, for all time, and all Eternity. div.head: The Art of Ticket-buying, or the way to help to Ruin the Seamen and their Families in their Service and Pay. In a Di≈øcour≈øe between Honesty, Poverty, Cruelty and Villany, as follows.

THIS Trade of Ticket-buying doth ≈øeem to have its Ri≈øe between Mi≈øery and Cruelty, or between cheating the King and Country, and Ruining the Seamen in their Pay; and as times grow wor≈øe, either in manners or mi≈øery, this Trade grows and increa≈øes as Mi≈øleto doth on a decaying Apple-Tree; as the Tree decays the Mi≈øle increa≈øeth: at fir≈øt Cruelty u≈øed to buy at 5 s profit in the pound, from the Seamen; but that was near 30 years pa≈øt, and they were cried out upon as extortioning Villains then, that have pa≈ø≈øed as mode≈øt men ≈øince: but ≈øince the times are grown more impudent in cheating the King, and ruining the Seamen, there be many have bought the Seamens pay at half lo≈øs; and not only content with that, but like inhumane Bea≈øts, that were wor≈øe than all other ≈øort of Bea≈øts, except Swine, in devouring their own Kind, there have been ≈øome that have bought at near Two Thirds Lo≈øs, and others, wor≈øt of all, have many of them ≈øwallowed up the poor Seamens Pay altogether, for nothing, except the charge of an Oath, and fal≈øe Power, if dead, or a fal≈øe Power, if out of the way, as hath of late been often proved: And this Villany and Extortion, and cheating the Loyal Seamen out of their Pay, hath been an unknown lo≈øs to the King, and unknown Ruin to the Seamens Families, and unknown Lo≈øs to tho≈øe who did friendly and hone≈øtly tru≈øt the Seamen, who by rea≈øon of their lo≈øing 7 or 8 l at a time, out of a Ticket bought by Cruelty, or being
≈øhamele≈øly deprived of it all by
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ llany, have not been able to pay their Debts, neither buy bread for them≈øelves and Families as they ought to do. And indeed what ≈øay you Poverty, is it not ≈øo?

sp.speaker: Pov.
sp.p: Indeed we have found it ≈øo, for while we have been ≈øhuffled from Ship to Ship, until our Friends knew not where to find us, it hath been an Opportunity for Villany to get Powers to cheat us of all our Pay: or if we fell ≈øick and died, for others to Q or R us; living, out of our Pay, if dead, to deprive our Wives and poor ruined Children. But, Hone≈øty, it ≈øeems, knows not what Names to call tho≈øe by that Ruin the Living, and fright many of them away; and Run the Dead, and let their Families cry for Ju≈øtice or Vengeance; and he knows not whether the next Age will call them barbarous Villains, or hard hearted Wretches, or Fools, or Knaves, or Jacobites, and Friends to French, or a mixture of all together, and Ruiners of their Country into the bargain.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Do not ≈øay what I think; for if ≈øo, you will ≈øay the la≈øt Age the Devil and the Je≈øuits debauched many people out of Religion and Morality, and now they would, if they could, cheat us out of our common Sen≈øes, and out of all our mony into the bargain, this next year or two; and there is too much cau≈øe of fear of this. But you mu≈øt ≈øay little of it for the fear of puzling. But as to the Lo≈øs of ≈øen≈øes, you may tell our Enemies of it; for it may be they know not how they have lo≈øt them, neither where to find them again, they are ≈øo dwindled away; or wa≈øht away. And as to the Lo≈øs of our Mony, you may let your Friends know of it; for your Enemies know it is worth more, our mill'd mony, to melt down, or carry to France or Sweedland, and ≈øome other parts, b ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Ten in the Hundred, ≈øome places, and near Twenty in other places; and they begin to laugh and ≈øay, Where is your mony? And that is too ≈øad to make a Je≈øt of.

sp.speaker: Villany.
sp.p: What a noi≈øe here is of mony: If I can buy Tickets at Ten ≈øhillings in the pound, I will buy; have you any?

sp.speaker: Pov.
sp.p:
I have a ≈ømall Ticket to ≈øell; I am in great di≈øtre≈øs. I was in ≈øuch a Ship, and fell ≈øick, and was Run out of my mony: but I crawled into the King's ≈øervice again, and now I have a
Ticket of 6 or 8 l and we have not a penny to buy a bit of Bread for my Family, neither a Rag of Cloaths for my ≈øelf, and yet I have been in the ≈øervice all this War; what will you give me for my Ticket, Cruelty?

sp.speaker: Cruelty.
sp.p: You ≈øay you were Run out of your Pay before, for being ≈øick; and who knows, tho you are di≈øcharged fair now, and have a Ticket, but you may go into another Ship, and continue there until you fall ≈øick, and be Run out of your Pay there, and for this al≈øo? sp.speaker: Poverty's Wife.
sp.p: That is very hard, and our Ca≈øe is mi≈øerable, however, mony we mu≈øt have; my poor Husband has not a penny to buy him a Shirt, or a pair of Shooes or Stockings to ≈øhift him, and I do not ≈øee what we can do; pray give me 3 l for it, and that is dreadful Lo≈øs.

sp.speaker: Cruelty.
sp.p: No, I will give you 50 s I do not know whether my brother Cruelty, or my ≈øi≈øter Villany would give ≈øo much; therefore do what pou will.

sp.speaker: Pov.

sp.speaker: Cruelty.
sp.p: I mu≈øt have a Bill of Sale, will co≈øt you 18 d and a Letter of Attorney, will co≈øt you 1 s My brother Cruelty does u≈øe to have a Bond too, which would co≈øt 1 s or 18 d more; and my ≈øi≈øter Cruelty does u≈øe to have a ≈ømall piece of meat, and ≈øome good drink al≈øo when ≈øhe payeth the mony: but I would have you ≈øee I am kind to you: and if any of your Ship's Company hath any more Tickets, I will buy them; for I have ≈øome mony lies by me that I received at the Office lately; and if they will ≈øell them, I will help them to mony for them, if they be good; ≈øend them.

sp.speaker: Pov.

sp.speaker: Cruelty.
sp.p: I have got the books ≈øearched, and I find there is 6 l 10 s due to you, if it be paid at la≈øt.

sp.speaker: Pov.

sp.speaker: Cruelty.

sp.speaker: Pov.
sp.p: I have not one Groat, if it were to ≈øave my ≈øelf and Family from Ruin and ≈øtarving: Therefore if you do not buy it, I cannot pay you: take it for 40 s anp pay the charges be≈øides.

sp.speaker: Cruelty.
sp.p: No, I will allow you 34 s and abate you all charges for Writings, and all will be about 6 s more, and that is 40 s in all together, tho you have but 34s. you ≈øelf.

sp.speaker: Poverty.
sp.p:
Take it: I cannot wait: and my poor Wife is forced to work hard for bread for our Children, to keep them from ≈øtarving, or being kept by the Pari≈øhes: And we owe mony to the Baker, and to the poor Chandler-woman, and that for a little Bread, or Chee≈øe, or now and then a quartern of Butter, to
help to keep my poor Family: And I owe for the Cloaths and Bedding I had to ≈øit me out to Sea, or I might have peri≈øhed for Cold, and not been able to ≈øerve the King, and this poor little mony cannot pay one Groat of tho≈øe Debts to either: And I being turn'd from Ship to Ship, if I am forc'd to ≈øell the re≈øt ≈øo, none knows what I and my poor Family mu≈øt do to live. sp.speaker: Villany.
sp.p: As to him you call Hone≈øty, I hate the Name of him, and intend never to have to do with him, he is ≈øo much a Fool ‚Ä¢ He had for a Year or 2 half ≈øpoiled this Trade of Ticket-buying; for he bought up almo≈øt all the Tickets that came near him, at 2 s in the Pound Profit to him≈øelf, and we could get but a few of tho≈øe, who did not know where to find ≈øuch a one of the Trade: And at la≈øt he bought at Three Shillings in the Pound Profit: And finding him≈øelf then to have now and then a Delay, he began to be weary of the Trade: and ≈øince, he and many of his Friends left off buying Cruelty can come in, for ≈øome bu≈øine≈øs by Whole≈øale.

sp.speaker: Pov.
sp.p:
The more is the pity that ≈øo few of his Friends will now buy any poor Seaman's Pay: And it is ≈øad for the poor Ruined Seamen. But it ≈øeems he was ≈øerved wor≈øe at the Office than the Heathen Romans u≈øed to do in point of Ju≈øtice: for he bought One Ticket in a Ship called the Ro≈øe, from New England, of Fifty Pound, and paid Forty Five Pound for it: and it was clear of all incumbrances when he bought it: and ≈øigned by the La≈øt Captain, and Pur≈øer Swain, and all the ≈øigning Officers, clear of all Debt. But ≈øome of the Commi≈ø≈øioners laid a ≈øtop on it for the U≈øe of the former Captain's Mother: and w ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ n petitioned about it, could neither tell wherefore, nor where „Äà‚óä„Äâ find her, and yet continued the ≈øtop: made Poor Pil
‚Ä¢ arlick wait near Two Years, and lo≈øe the intere≈øt of the mony,
aboot ≈øix Pound, be at the charge to go and ≈øend into City and Country, to find out the Captain's Mother: and one of their Officers gave them under his Hand, he had enquired, and ≈øhe could not be found: And after waiting ≈øo long, and the party that earned the mony appearing, who was preferr'd to a Lieutenant's Place, and demanding his mony to be paid to Hone≈øty, his Attorney; and ≈øaid, None other ever had power from him: And yet they would not let it be paid, until a Lawyer appeared, and claimed ≈øome mony due to the Captain, but had nothing to ≈øhow for it; and then the ≈øtop was taken off lamely; that is to be paid to them that had the be≈øt Power, when there was never any Power they could find or hear of, ever to appear for it, be≈øides poor filly Hone≈øty: and he was Kept out of his mony until the books were made up, and then had it paid by a Li≈øt: and then Pur≈øer Swain, that was Pur≈øer of the Ship, had five Pound ≈øtopped out of it for Tobacco, altho there was none due, and doth detain the mony ≈øtill, altho he hath heard of it ≈øo much: and poor None≈øty knows not whether he did not lo≈øe twice as much by his mony being ≈øtopped ≈øo unju≈øtly from him by the Commi≈ø≈øioners, or by the 5 l ≈øtopped for the Pur≈øer, neither which of them all will be the hone≈øte≈øt men when they come to die, or look blacke≈øt in the face Living or Dying.

sp.speaker: Cruelty.
sp.p:
You have told ≈øome part how Hone≈øty was ≈øerved in that Ca≈øe, that he never would ≈øpeak of; but you have not told how many Tickets he hath by him, or his Friends, that the mony is ≈øaid to be paid the parties, and they know not where to find the parties; and Hone≈øty never told the Riddle of that Trick, That if poor Seamens Wives have their Husbands Tickets detained by the Captains, they may cry their Eyes out before they get a penny of Mony without Tickets: But when Tickets are in ≈øome hands, then mony can be ≈øaid to be paid the parties, or to Jack-a-Noaks, or Joan-a-Styles; and the Tickets may ≈øerve for the Ages to come, to wonder why there ≈øhould not be a certain Rule, a certain Payment, and a certain Law in the Seamens Payment; and not lay all the blame on Cruelty, in buying; for he commonly gives ≈øomething for what he buyeth

sp.speaker: Pov.
sp.p: Now I think of it, pray Hone≈øty, I do hear, ≈øince you made ≈øuch a Noi≈øe this 2 Years, of ≈øome Officers cheating the King, and the Seamen of their Tickets and Pay, there is an Order, they mu≈øt receive no man's Pay but their own; and I hear ≈øome of them are vexed ≈øadly at You: What mu≈øt they do now with ≈øuch Tickets, pray, to get a penny for them?

sp.speaker: Hone≈øty.
sp.p: I will not ≈øay what they mu≈øt do, but I will ≈øay, if they be not prevented; they that plea≈øe to give their mind to it, and have Tickets at their command, I fear can get Powers fill'd up, and witne≈ø≈øed by them≈øelves, or other Officers, and leave Blanks for ≈øuch Names to receive them, as may ≈øerve to be put in afterwards: And therefore it was my Advice, That if the Parliament plea≈øed, they ≈øhould make it Felony and Tran≈øportation to receive a Seaman's Pay by a wrong power, for time to come: And if they had been Seamen, and cheated of their Pay, ten times as often as men have Robbed on the High-way, or had their Pockets pickt at Land, they would have ≈øtriv'd to make a Law again≈øt cheating, for time tu come, and not left it to will and plea≈øure, to hinder ≈ømall Officers from receiving mony by a Lawful Power, although they fed them and cloathed them ≈øeveral Years before, to a≈ø≈øi≈øt them whsle they ≈øerved the King, and in the mean time leave ≈øo many ways open to cheat the King and the Seamen by other Officers ≈øtill in private ways, in≈øtead of tho≈øe Hundreds of Pounds in a Ship received for the Captains, of Seamens Pay publickly, in former Years.

sp.speaker: Poverty.
sp.p:
It is a Wonder that you will meddle with ≈øuch Di≈øea≈øes as are Noli me tangeries; that though they are heard of publickly now and then, as the Noli me tangere is in the Weekly Bill, yet hardly One in an Hundred knows what a dreadful Di≈øtemper it is, although ≈øome die of the ≈øame: And therefore, pray if you meet with any Offices that are infected
with the Ruining and Plaguing of the Seamen, as the Hou≈øes of ≈øome were of Old in I≈ørael, with the Lepro≈øie, that they could never be clean≈øed until the very Walls were ≈øcraped; And although the whole Prie≈øthood ≈øhould by the Law of God Judge them Unclean, pray Hone≈øty ≈øay no more of it. And when you hear I have been ≈øick a Year or Two, or in the Ho≈øpitals, and Run out of my Pay, to the Ruin of my Family; and I and my Family cry and groan to Heaven for Relief or Vengeance; and others of my Poor Poverty Brethren be crying to Heaven and Hell for Damnation again≈øt them that Ruin them, and Run away to other Nations, to ≈øee if there be Mercy and Ju≈øtice there; pray hold your Peace for time to come; Let things ≈øink or ≈øwim, you have done your Duty; and you being ≈øen≈øible every Leaf you write, mu≈øt be ≈øuch as mu≈øt be true before God and man, as to the ≈øub≈øtance of it. And now you may admire at the mercy of God in keeping you hitherro, as in mercy you have been hitherto.

sp.speaker: Hone≈øty.
sp.p: That is true, and that I only tru≈øt to the infinite Free Grace, and Free Love and Rich mercy of God to me and all mine, in Chri≈øt Je≈øus our Lord and only Saviour, for all Time and all Eternity, de≈øiring the Eternal God to be our Refuge and Portion for ever: And that underneath us may be his Everla≈øting Arms of Love and mercy, for all Time and all Eternity, to us and all ours. sp.speaker: Poverty.
sp.p:
You have cho≈øen well: but do not you con≈øider, That there was an Age wherein it was ≈øaid, Hold thy peace, for we may not mention the Name of our God? But do not you think, that tho≈øe ≈øad and barbarous Villains, who do Cheat, and Ruin, and De≈øtroy the Seamens Pay and Families in this Age, do neither fear God, nor Regard man, but are as Ungodly, Hard-hearted, Ca≈øe-hardned Brutes, that ≈øeem as the Boy ≈øaid by his Learning the Primmer, ≈øome of them to be pa≈øt the Graces, and to be come almo≈øt as far as the Devil and all his Works: And as it was ≈øaid of the Gentleman by his Jackanapes, An Ill Life may Expect an Ill
End. Therefore pray be wary how you Di≈øcour≈øe about tho≈øe ≈øort of men.

sp.speaker: Hone≈øty.
sp.p:
I ble≈øs God I have no prejudice again≈øt the Per≈øons of any men in England; and know not any man in England but I would ≈øhew him a civil kindne≈øs; and it may be there is hardly a man but would do the like by me, if occa≈øion were; and I find Anger is often Folly, but malice is the Devil, and a dreadful burden certainly for any man to carry: and I ble≈øs God who keeps me clear of that hitherto, as I de≈øire to be kept from flattery, and that makes me write ≈øuch plain hone≈øt homely Engli≈øh, to ≈øerve my King and Country, without much minding who are plea≈øed or di≈øplea≈øed: and that makes me labour as heartily to endeavour the pre≈øerving of our Lives and Liberties, and encouragement of our Engli≈øh Seamen, with as much earne≈øtne≈øs as ever I heard of any did to ≈øecure a Wall or Bank that was to keep out the Sea from drowning the Country: And therefore having ≈øaid it may be too much, I may pa≈øs over a great part of the Art of Ticket-buying in ≈øilence, for want of Time and Patience, and ≈øo ≈øay little of the Buyers Skill in getting the poor Wretches in that are not in the greate≈øt of mi≈øeries, making them drunk, and getting their Pay as they plea≈øe: Or of any buying at Five Shillings, and paying them part of their money, and then afterwards will have them at Ten Shillings Profit, or demand their money again, and extort money for. Extortioning Intere≈øt, be≈øides Trouble, if they cannot pay the money. Neither mind I to repre≈øent how there have been ≈øome Hundreds of Pounds worth of Tickets offered without Powers at a time in One Ship: Neither the making out of Twenty Hogs, alias, Seamens Tickets in One Ship, allowed about Fifty men: Neither the very great multitudes of Tickets Captains Clerks have made out privately for Seamens Pay: Neither need I trouble my Head for time to come, much more than other men, if the King and the Nation ≈øhould ever be found to be cheated of a ≈øixth part of their money: for if I pay about Twelve Pound the Year this War: Taxes, as I have done, it is but Forty ≈øhillings Charge Extraordinary the
Year: And I ≈øuppo≈øe I have printed as many Thou≈øand ≈øheets of Paper, freely to inform the mo≈øt Honourable Hou≈øes of Parliament, and the≈øe Nations this La≈øt Three Years, as hath co≈øt me about Ten Years Purcha≈øe, for my ≈øixth part of the ≈øaid Twelve Pound: And I ble≈øs God I was never imployed by any to do it, but as the good will and plea≈øure of God ≈øtirred me up out of a true de≈øign to ≈øerve God, and my King and Country: and I never had, to my knowledge, Ten ≈øhillings advantage from all others for the ≈øame. And I am of no Club, nor of no Faction; neither am I any mens In≈øtrument or Tool: ≈øo that if I do any ≈øervice, the glory will be to God, and the benefit to the≈øe Nations: And if I mi≈øtake, and ≈øuffer for it, I mu≈øt ≈øubmit with Humility, Love and Patience. And ≈øo intreating the pardon of his mo≈øt gracious Maje≈øty, and the Two mo≈øt Honourable Hou≈øes of Parliament, for what is ami≈øs: and begging of the Eternal Jehovah for his Grace and Ble≈ø≈øing on his Maje≈øty, our mo≈øt gracious King William, and on the Parliament and People of the≈øe Nations: and on me and all my Family, I ≈øub≈øcribe my ≈øelf a faithful Subject to his Maje≈øty, and Servant to him and all good men, while I remain to be,

div.head: POSTSCRIPT.
div.p:
SInce I writ my fir≈øt book of the Seamens mi≈øeries, and pre≈øented 500 of them to the 2 mo≈øt Honourable Hou≈øes of Parliament, who were graciou≈øly plea≈øed to pa≈øs by my infirmities, in repre≈øenting the fame; for which I am in all humble duty obliged to be thankful to them. And I have pre≈øumed to attempt the foregoing rough Peice, being heartily willing any that can repre≈øent better Rules for the ≈øafety and encouragement of the Seamen, to ≈øerve his gracious Maje≈øty King William, and the Nation, I ≈øhall rejoice. Neither do I ≈øee how Trade≈ømen can e≈øcape Ruin for want of Trade, if there be not mony to Trade, and Exchange, and pay the poor. And the Lo≈øs of Trade already to ≈øome I fear hath been, and is like to be ten times wor≈øe than their Taxes; and unle≈øs there be a new Coinage, that is about 3 Ounces to 20 s or the Mill'd mony rai≈øed to 6 s and 8 d the Crown Peice, I fear whoever lives 9 months, will ≈øee hardly any of it pa≈ø≈øing about; and for Guinea's, they are at pre≈øent a perfect Plague and Trick to mankind, and a means for men to prey upon one another; and if they fall, will be carried away; but if ≈øetled at but 28 s the Guinea certain, would pay in Taxes, and out again; and there might be One per Cent. allowed for profit of tho≈øe who carried Silver and Gold to Coin; and the re≈øt to go towards the Calling in the Fragments of our Old Mony at la≈øt; And there would never want Silver nor Coiners; and we ≈øhould be in a few Years full of mony, to the Joy of the King and Country, and Landlord and Tenant: And this I would repre≈øent,
that our Seamen at Sea, and the common people at Land, tho called the Mobilly, have been entirely in the Intere≈øt of our gracious King William, and this Nation.
